chapter.title: Extending the IDE
chapter.para: There are several ways to extend the functionality of the &Omnetpp; IDE. The Simulation IDE is based on the Eclipse platform, and extends it with new editors, views, wizards, and other functionality.

sect1.title: Installing new features
sect1.para: Because the IDE is based on the Eclipse platform, it is possible to add additional features that are available for Eclipse. The installation procedure is exactly the same as with a standard Eclipse distribution. Choose the ``Help | Install New Software...'' menu item and select an existing Update Site to work with or add a new Site (using the site URL) to the Available Software Sites. After the selection you can browse and install the packages the site offers.

To read about installing new software into your IDE, please visit the ``Updating and installing software'' topic in the ``Workbench User Guide''. You can find the online help system in the ``Help | Help Contents'' menu.
sect1.tip: There are thousands of useful components and extensions for Eclipse. The best places to start looking for extensions are the Eclipse Marketplace (http://marketplace.eclipse.org/) and the Eclipse Plugins info site (http://www.eclipse-plugins.info).

sect1.title: Adding new Wizards
sect1.para: In addition to the possibility to add new, independent software features to the &Omnetpp; IDE, it has its own extension mechanisms. One of the easiest ways to extend the IDE is by adding new Wizards to it. Wizards can be used to create new projects, simulations or files using simple templates. They can be created without writing any code in Java and can be installed by simply copying the wizard's code into the ``templates'' folder of an &Omnetpp; project. Wizards are activated automatically once their project is opened. This is a difference compared to the normal Elcipse extensions which are always active.
sect1.tip: You can read more about Wizards in the ``IDE Customization Guide'' document

sect1.title: Project specific extensions
sect1.para: While it is possible to install an Eclipse plugin directly into the &Omnetpp; IDE, sometimes we need extensions that are used only by a single simulation project (e.g. special project related views or editors). These extensions are useful only if we are working with that project and are meaningless for other projects.

It is possible to install an Eclipse plugin into a single project by simply creating a ``plugins'' folder in the root of the project and copying the plugin JAR file there. This extension mechanism allows the distribution of model specific IDE extensions inside a simulation project. Plugins and wizards - distributed with a project - are automatically activated when the host project is opened.
Eclipse plugin JAR files can be created using the ``Plugin Development Environment''. The &Omnetpp; IDE does not contain the ``PDE'' by default, however it can be easily installed if need.
sect1.tip: Read the ``&Omnetpp; IDE Development Guide'' for more information about how to install the PDE and how to develop plugin extensions for the IDE
